children.text: Performance and Production
The student will demonstrate correct alignment while performing axial movements, including bending, twisting, swinging, and stretching.
The student will demonstrate correct alignment while performing basic locomotor sequences, including walking, running, hopping, jumping, leaping, galloping, skipping, and sliding.
The student will develop dance technique skills and movement vocabulary through replication.
The student will perform short movement sequences that employ specific space, shape, time, rhythm, energy, and effort requirements.
The student will identify performance practices that promote safe technique and will recognize incorrect performance of physical skills, which can result in injury.
The student will develop personal movement invention using improvisational skills, including imitation, mirroring, and shadowing.
The student will create and perform short choreographic studies that manipulate the elements of space, shape, time, rhythm, energy, and effort.
The student will collaboratively create and perform short choreographic studies that use simple compositional forms, including unison, theme and variation, and canon.
The student will rehearse choreographed dances and execute those dances in performance.

The student will
  1. identify and use safety procedures in all dance settings; and
  2. use proper care with theatre facilities, equipment, and costumes.
The student will participate in production activities for dance performance (e.g., publicity, running crew, costume care, strike and clean-up).
Cultural Context and Dance History
The student will identify similarities and differences in dance styles from various cultures and historical periods.
The student will research the role of social and folk dance forms in American history.
The student will identify dance as a form of expression, communication, ceremony, and entertainment.
The student will identify the roles of performers and audiences for various forms of dance.
The student will identify various dance professions.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will describe in oral and written form personal work and the work of others in choreography and performance, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.
The student will view live and recorded dance performances and describe the similarities and differences in composition and style, using oral and written responses.
Aesthetics
The student will define aesthetics and discuss how it is reflected in dance arts and in everyday life.
The student will discuss ways in which a dance can evoke sensory, emotional, and intellectual responses.
The student will discuss ways in which aesthetic responses to works of dance differ from judgment and criticism.
Performance and Production
The student will demonstrate correct alignment while standing in a variety of dance shapes and while moving through space.
The student will develop dance technique skills and movement vocabulary, including strength, flexibility, coordination, endurance, balance, and replication.
The student will perform extended movement sequences that employ a variety of space, shape, time, rhythm, energy, and effort requirements.

The student will demonstrate performance practices (e.g., warm-up, cool-down, nutritional awareness, hydration) and will identify the relationship between incorrect execution of physical skills and dance injuries.
The student will develop personal movement invention skills and improvisation skills.
The student will develop movement invention skills to express emotional and/or narrative content.

The student will create choreographic studies for solo, duets, or trios that
  1. manipulate the elements of space, shape, time, rhythm, energy, and effort to communicate choreographic intent;
  2. demonstrate the elements of composition, including unity, variety, intent, development, climax, and resolution; and
  3. use a variety of compositional forms, including unison, theme and variation, canon, ABA, and rondo.
The student will demonstrate in performance a range of performance skills, including rhythmic and movement accuracy.

The student will
  1. identify and use safety procedures in all dance settings; and
  2. use proper care with theatre facilities, equipment, and costumes.

The student will participate in various production support roles (e.g., publicity, fund-raising, house management, costume crew, lighting crew, running crew, strike and clean-up) for dance performance.
Cultural Context and Dance History
The student will identify periods and styles of dance and artists who contributed to the development of dance as a concert art form prior to 1900.
The student will identify distinguishing features of various dance forms belonging to past and present world cultures, styles, periods, and artists.
The student will identify, research, and discuss how dance reflects and records history and culture.
The student will identify various dance-related professions, including those of studio personnel, production personnel, and collaborating artists.
The student will demonstrate skill in communicating information by researching current dance institutions in the community and the commonwealth.
Judgment and Criticism
The student will describe, interpret, and evaluate dance works for choreographic, performance, and production elements, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.

The student will view and compare dance performance to other art forms (e.g., visual arts, music, film, theatre, literature) and analyze similarities, differences, and the expression of common themes, using oral and written responses.
The student will discuss artistic choices in composition and performance, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.
The student will identify the role of the dance critic.
Aesthetics
The student will view dance performances and discuss the elements of choreography, performance, music, costuming, and lighting design within each dance work that evoke aesthetic responses.
The student will discuss how personal experience, culture, and current events shape individual aesthetic preferences.
The student will identify aesthetic characteristics within various dance styles.
The student will identify how the aesthetics of a culture influence dance arts.
Performance and Production
The student will maintain correct alignment while performing complex movement sequences.
The student will develop dance technique skills and movement vocabulary, including strength, flexibility, coordination, endurance, balance, replication, kinesthetic awareness, and self-evaluation.
The student will perform a variety of complex movement sequences that employ a wide range of space, shape, time, rhythm, energy, and effort requirements.
The student will identify implications for performance and injury prevention resulting from variations in physical structure and individual choices regarding health and wellness.
The student will participate in solo and group improvisations in response to a variety of environments and props.

The student will choreograph small-group dances that
  1. demonstrate manipulation and development of movement phrases;
  2. use a variety of compositional elements; and
  3. use a variety of compositional forms.
The student will demonstrate a range of performance skills, including dynamics, musicality, movement execution, and choreographic intent, in performance.

The student will
  1. identify and use safety procedures in all dance settings; and
  2. use proper care with theatre facilities, equipment, and costumes.

The student will participate in various production roles (e.g., those of choreographer, costume designer, stage manager, house manager, public relations) that involve leadership or design responsibilities for dance performance.
Cultural Context and Dance History
The student will identify periods and styles of dance and artists who contributed to the development of dance as a concert art form from 1900 to the present.
The student will identify, research, and discuss the effects of dance as an art form on individuals, groups, and cultures.

The student will research a variety of careers in the dance profession, including those of performers, choreographers, management and production personnel, collaborating artists, health professionals, and dance scholars.
The student will examine and discuss the impact of technology on the art of dance through time.
The student will demonstrate skill in communicating information by researching current dance institutions in the community, commonwealth, and world.
Judgment and Criticism

The student will describe, interpret, and evaluate in oral and written form, criteria that affect quality in a dance and the realization of choreographic intent, including
  1. development of movement phrases;
  2. elements of composition and compositional form;
  3. technical skill of the performers;
  4. production elements; and
  5. impact of the dance performance as a whole.
The student will discuss ways in which other art forms (e.g., visual arts, music, film, theatre, literature) and technology can contribute to dance performance.
The student will discuss, analyze, and evaluate artistic choices in composition and performance, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.
The student will identify the role of the dance critic and compare and contrast a variety of dance critiques.
Aesthetics
The student will view live and recorded dance performances and discuss aesthetic responses, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.
The student will investigate how a dance can be viewed from a variety of aesthetic stances (e.g., classicism, postmodernism).
The student will analyze and articulate his/her personal aesthetic and the criteria upon which that aesthetic is based, using appropriate dance arts vocabulary and terminology.
The student will analyze and discuss relationships between works of art in terms of opposing aesthetic views.
The student will study, analyze, interpret, and relate the aesthetic qualities of the art works of others to personal work.
The student will justify personal perceptions of an artist's intent, using visual clues and research.
The student will discuss in writing the impact of contemporary art on the development of a personal style.
